required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of Gene Polymorphism After Transcranial Cranial Direct Current Stimulation on the Corticobulbar Excitability
clinical_study.official_title: Role of Genetic Polymorphism in Neuroplasticity Involved in Dysphagia Recovery- Part 2

brief_summary.textblock: This study aims to examine the effects of transcranial direct current stimulation at corticobulbar excitability in individuals with different gene polymorphism.

detailed_description.textblock: The effects of TDCS on corticobulbar excitability of the brain after inhibitory pre-conditioning will be compared in patients with different BDNF phenotypes

primary_outcome.time_frame: Immediately after single conditioning the brain
primary_outcome.description: Change of Brain corticobulbar excitability by motor evoked potentials

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Immediate after single conditioning the brain
secondary_outcome.description: Change of tongue pressure measurement by Intra oral pressure assessment

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Immediate after single conditioning the brain
secondary_outcome.description: Change of Electrophysiological responses of swallowing - With the use of a laryngeal transducer, will measure the mylohyoid amplitude

arm_group.description: Healthy adults - Participants will receive single session of tdcs after application

intervention.description: application of optimised parameters of tDCS (anodal stimulation, 1.5 mA, 10 min) over the unconditioned hemisphere reverses the brain and behavioural consequences of inhibitory pre-conditioning

biospec_descr.textblock: DNA of gene polymorphism from the Polymorphisms in brain-derived neurotrophic factor

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age 19-40 years
- Informed consent
Exclusion Criteria:
- History of epilepsy
- Presence of cardiac pacemaker
- previous brain surgery
- previous swallowing problems
- current use of medication which acts on the central nervous system
- presence of implanted metal intracranially

facility.name: Department of Rehabilitation Medicine Bucheon St Mary's Hospital, Catholic University of Korea, College of Medicine

responsible_party.investigator_title: Sun Im, Assistant Professor, The Catholic University of Korea
